awd_abstract_narration:
Chestnut Hill College (CHC) in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, is designing, developing, and implementing a new degree program to produce  cybersecurity professionals, an employment sector with a critical shortage throughout the country. CHC's cybersecurity program will be the first undergraduate degree to be offered in the Philadelphia region. Fifteen students are expected to enroll as new cybersecurity majors each year. The unique factors of the program are: (1) involving  industry experts with real-world experience in the creation and implementation of the academic curriculum, (2) wide-ranging infusion of cybersecurity principles in all information technology and computer science curricula offered by CHC, and (3) hands-on  skills development with actual hardware and software, not just virtual environments.  

The interaction with the cybersecurity community will allow CHC to incorporate state-of-the art applications, based on real world situations, into the development of the new academic program. In addition to assisting with curriculum design, subject matter experts will serve as adjunct teachers.  All recruited subject matter experts have extensive backgrounds in cybersecurity and are recognized as leaders in the industry and government agencies, such as the FBI and DHS.  The opportunities for students to work with real-world experts will enhance their understanding of the role of cybersecurity in today's complicated technology environment. CHC will share the process of creating the new curriculum through the academic--industry expert partnership with other colleges throughout the nation.  In addition, the team will apply for the designation as a National Centers of Academic Excellence (CAE) program, jointly sponsored by The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and The National Security Agency (NSA).

por.por_cntn:
The National Science Foundation’s Award for the “CHC Cyber Sentinels Program” provided the necessary resources for faculty and administration at Chestnut Hill College (CHC) to build a new 4-yr undergraduate science degree in Cybersecurity.  

The award funding made it possible for CHC to recruit subject matter experts (SMEs) to assist with the design of the curriculum and to teach in the newly created courses.  These experts were pulled from both government and private industries, and possessed knowledge of the skills desired by cybersecurity employers. Under the guidance of the experts recruited, students have learned skills and concepts that the industry expects of cybersecurity employees.

The new program was also built with the National Security Agency and Department of Homeland Security’s Center of Academic Excellence, Cyber Defense Education (NSA/DHS CAE-CDE) knowledge units mapped to course learning outcomes, along with the alignment to objectives from the National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education (NICE). The college intends to pursue this program certification in the near future.

CHC’s new undergraduate program in Cybersecurity exceeded the enrollments estimated in the award proposal.  Those enrollments consist of a significant percentage of underrepresented groups in the cybersecurity field.

Also accomplished under the grant, several new program-to-program articulation agreements were formed between 2-yr community colleges and CHC, streamlining the academic transfer process and creating financially strategic degrees for transfer students.

The award also provided funding for more than one dozen students to attempt industry certification tests without financial risk. Several students have certified in CompTIA’s Security+ and Network+ under the NSF award. Based on our survey of eligible students, a large majority stated that they would not take certification tests due to the financial risk of failure.  In response, we worked with the college bookstore and partnered with certification organizations to offer test vouchers for sale through the college bookstore. 

Students in the program were able to use knowledge and skills learned at CHC to assist local businesses and individuals in improving their cybersecurity posture. In addition, they were able to use their knowledge and skills to augment the resources in the CHC Information Technology Department, and contributed to cybersecurity awareness campaigns and employee training.

A number of graduates of the program now have successful careers in cybersecurity in both public and private sectors. These students are engaged in meaningful work in the cybersecurity field and contributing to increased cybersecurity awareness, defense, and risk management.

There were also secondary benefits due to the involvement in the award, which although were not directly funded, stemmed from the existence of CHC’s undergraduate program in cybersecurity, with the support of the college.  These opportunities include, but were not limited to: alliances with professional organizations; increased partnerships for internships and job pathways; hosted annual cybersecurity conferences; increased cyber-lab space; adapted pedagogy; interdisciplinary involvement in other courses/majors; hardware/software upgrades; improved CHC cybersecurity posture; created cybersecurity club and hacking team; and implemented a cybersecurity graduate program as pathway for students who want to continue their cybersecurity education.  In short, the benefits of the work done under the award has extended far beyond the outcomes which were originally outlined in the proposal.

In summary, CHC achieved the goals outlined in our Cyber Sentinels proposal. CHC is very grateful to the National Science Foundation (NSF) for providing this award.  As academia operates on limited budgets, the additional funding from NSF allowed the college to create this new program.  Without the award, program startup would have taken much longer to achieve, or not come to fruition at all. The timely creation of this program has created valuable career opportunities for graduating students and has already increased the number of skilled workers available in an industry that remains understaffed.


Last Modified: 01/13/2022
Modified by: Pamela King
